t: Job 33
Elihu Confronts Job
But*pn now, Job, pay attention to my speech, and*ln listen to all my words.
I*ln am going to open my mouth; my*ln tongue will form words on my palate.
My*ln words come from my upright heart, and*ln my lips speak with sincerity what they know.
The*ln Spirit of God has made me, and*ln the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
Refute*ln me if you can. Prepare*ln your case against me; take your stand.
I*ln am just like you before God; I*ln was also pinched off from a piece of clay.
Fear*ln of me should not terrify you; no*ln pressure from me should weigh you down.
Surely*pn you have spoken in my hearing, and*ln I have heard these very words:
“I*ln am pure, without transgression; I*ln am clean and have no iniquity.
But*ln he finds reasons to oppose me; he*ln regards me as his enemy.
He*ln puts my feet in the stocks; he*ln stands watch over all my paths.”
But*pn I tell you that you are wrong in this matter, since*ln God is greater than man.
Why*ln do you take him to court for*ln not answering anything a person asks?
For*ln God speaks time and again, but*ln a person may not notice it.
In*ln a dream, a vision in the night, when*ln deep sleep comes over people as*ln they slumber on their beds,
he*ln uncovers their ears and*ln terrifies them with warnings,
in*ln order to turn a person from his actions and*ln suppress the pride of a person.
God*ln spares his soul from the Pit, his*ln life from crossing the river of death.
A*ln person may be disciplined on his bed with pain and*ln constant distress in his bones,
so*ln that he detests bread, and*ln his soul despises his favorite food.
His*ln flesh wastes away to nothing, and*ln his unseen bones stick out.
He*ln draws near to the Pit, and*ln his life to the executioners.
If*ln there is an angel on his side, one*ln mediator out of a thousand, to*ln tell a person what is right for him
and*ln to be gracious to him and say, “Spare*ln him from going down to the Pit; I*ln have found a ransom,”
then*ln his flesh will be healthier than in his youth, and*ln he will return to the days of his youthful vigor.
He*ln will pray to God, and God will delight in him. That*ln person will see his face with a shout of joy, and*ln God will restore his righteousness to him.
He*ln will look at men and say, “I*ln have sinned and perverted what was right; yet*ln I did not get what I deserved.
He*ln redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit, and*ln I will continue to see the light.”
God*ln certainly does all these things two*ln or three times to a person
in*ln order to turn him back from the Pit, so*ln he may shine with the light of life.
Pay*ln attention, Job, and listen to me. Be*ln quiet, and I will speak.
But*ln if you have something to say, answer me; speak,*ln for I would like to justify you.
If*ln not, then listen to me; be*ln quiet, and I will teach you wisdom.
